post.body:
https://ruqqus.com/+changelog/post/4qe6/ruqqus-222-politics-filter

Every single time there's any major post, I'm always way too late to try and join the discussion. But somehow literally *everyone else* knows about it the millisecond it's posted, and posts their comments in a flash if they have anything to say. Is there some kind of notification system that I don't have enabled?
post.body_html:
https://ruqqus.com/+changelog/post/4qe6/ruqqus-222-politics-filter

Every single time there's any major post, I'm always way too late to try and join the discussion. But somehow literally everyone else knows about it the millisecond it's posted, and posts their comments in a flash if they have anything to say. Is there some kind of notification system that I don't have enabled?

body: Even still, I'm not sure how the exact same people always happen to be online the moment it's posted. If you don't know that's okay, lots of people around here seem to be capable of doing almost anything, in some cases even stuff that doesn't seem possible. That's why I ask these sorts of questions a lot, because I feel alone not having superpowers and all. Maybe some time someone will finally know of an answer.

body: I know but no one is constantly browsing New 24/7 (and the front page and #announcements if it's an admin post). Some of the people who are always first to these threads I know are not always online, and even if some of them are they can't be browsing only those three pages the whole time. Yet they never fail to arrive at every admin post or highly upvoted meta thread first, within minutes or seconds of its being posted.

body:
It's too late to actually join the discussion though. If you comment any time after the first 20-30 minutes no one will even see it.

In any case, I've always had problems with a lot of other people doing insanely hard things like it's a cakewalk, and I never could. Since it's always the same people who show up first to these threads, this is probably one of those things and I was hoping someone who does could give me some answers.
body_html:
It's too late to actually join the discussion though. If you comment any time after the first 20-30 minutes no one will even see it.

In any case, I've always had problems with a lot of other people doing insanely hard things like it's a cakewalk, and I never could. Since it's always the same people who show up first to these threads, this is probably one of those things and I was hoping someone who does could give me some answers.

body: True, but who checks every single discord message (I barely use it and even I get too many). Plus I know for a fact that many of these people aren't online 24/7, in fact some of them are online even less often than they are offline. But they always show up to these threads within literally < 5 minutes every single time. Discord also doesn't explain it because this also happens with regular meta threads that explode, which wouldn't be posted in #announcements or stickied to the top of ruqqus immediately, yet these same users are still always the first ones to know about it. One of them is also the author of these posts way more often than other users.
body_html: True, but who checks every single discord message (I barely use it and even I get too many). Plus I know for a fact that many of these people aren't online 24/7, in fact some of them are online even less often than they are offline. body:
![](https://i.imgur.com/yhuN737.png)

For one, I don't have a life. Check my comments and find out for yourself. Two, some of these people do have a life, and three, either way many of them I know for a fact aren't on 24/7, and even the ones that are wouldn't be browsing the front page and New the whole time looking for admin and meta threads. And a lot of the people who *are* online most of the time, many of the power users, also can't do this.

body:
They only added the politics filter yesterday, you've been getting bombarded with coins since they were added. The other thing is that your posts also get a lot of upvotes nearly every single time, with very few below 30-40 and most of them approaching or above 100. The portion of your posts that get coins is also way higher than the rest of the posts in the guilds.

As for me, I'm the only one on the site who's still never even gotten one coin. I don't post a lot because unlike every other person on the planet finding even the most basic content is nearly impossible for me. But even when I do, the post doesn't do very well. It usually only gets about 15-30 upvotes. That's not uncommon in +foxes but it doesn't happen every time like it does me. And this happens in other guilds too.

EDIT: I just got a coin for my previous comment. But it was when talking about coins, which usually makes people want to give coins (like how talking about reddit ~~gold~~ premium makes people gild everything), not from a legitimate post, so it doesn't count. But still pretty cool to have though, thanks to whoever bought it for me.
body_html:
They only added the politics filter yesterday, you've been getting bombarded with coins since they were added. The other thing is that your posts also get a lot of upvotes nearly every single time, with very few below 30-40 and most of them approaching or above 100. The portion of your posts that get coins is also way higher than the rest of the posts in the guilds.

As for me, I'm the only one on the site who's still never even gotten one coin. I don't post a lot because unlike every other person on the planet finding even the most basic content is nearly impossible for me. But even when I do, the post doesn't do very well. It usually only gets about 15-30 upvotes. That's not uncommon in +foxes but it doesn't happen every time like it does me. And this happens in other guilds too.

EDIT: I just got a coin for my previous comment. But it was when talking about coins, which usually makes people want to give coins (like how talking about reddit gold premium makes people gild everything), not from a legitimate post, so it doesn't count. But still pretty cool to have though, thanks to whoever bought it for me.

post.body: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.

body:
> creative

Oh yeah, I'm not the greatest in that department either. I can't even think of good titles for ruqqus posts. The most obvious solutions to problems go right over my head. And my mind can do nothing but robotically copy what others have done for me.

> Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

You're clearly still at a high enough level to do that though. I'm not, nothing ever clicks with me no matter how badly I want it to. The only thing that distinguishes me from the average person is that I haven't given up yet upon finding out that I'm not cut out, so I'm a little better than them. But maybe that's not such a good thing if I have no hope of doing anything but failing miserably at even the smallest things. The problem is, I can't do what I want to do, because I'm not capable of it. But everyone else is. After years of practicing and having dreams I'm still nowhere even close to where everyone else doing the same thing *started out* with a fraction of the effort. My improvements are always extremely minor and localized to a specific procedure, and happen very slowly, meaning I'm already at my ceiling. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.
body_html:
creative

You're clearly still at a high enough level to do that though. I'm not, nothing ever clicks with me no matter how badly I want it to. The only thing that distinguishes me from the average person is that I haven't given up yet upon finding out that I'm not cut out, so I'm a little better than them. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.

parent.body: I'll just say this... some of the biggest bands of all time were people who just made creative use of their limited abilities. As a musician myself I can speak to this. I know how high my skill ceiling goes. I reach a certain point and I can play no faster. Every musician comes to this point and then learns to make creative use of what they have. Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

body:
> my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome.

Exactly, so there's no hope for it to ever change. I'll always be hopelessly dull.

> Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

That's true for a lot of people, depending on whether they want results or challenge. I wouldn't necessarily be opposed to that myself for certain subjects. But remember I can't even come up with halfway decent titles for ruqqus posts, even when spending a half hour trying to do so. *Everyone* else can at least do that in under a minute. My creativity is almost zero. Better than *nothing* I guess, but not enough to keep things enjoyable.

> If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

Ironically most people in my career path kind of fake their way through it and get good jobs without actually being any good, so I'll be fine with that. And most people are impressed with me because they just gave up entirely when they found out they weren't cut out for it. But the problem arises when I want to actually do things for myself, and I'm not good enough to be able to. I can ask other people to do it for me, but I don't like that idea. I don't want to have to rely on other people for things I'm also interested in. For one, I have to sacrifice my control over it, two I'll either have to burden someone or pay for it, and most importantly it takes all the fun and joy out of doing it myself. This is especially frustrating when everyone else I know *is* good enough to do things themselves, at least some of the things they're into, perhaps all of them.
body_html:
my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome.

Exactly, so there's no hope for it to ever change. I'll always be hopelessly dull.

Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

That's true for a lot of people, depending on whether they want results or challenge. I wouldn't necessarily be opposed to that myself for certain subjects. But remember I can't even come up with halfway decent titles for ruqqus posts, even when spending a half hour trying to do so. Everyone else can at least do that in under a minute. My creativity is almost zero. Better than nothing I guess, but not enough to keep things enjoyable.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

Ironically most people in my career path kind of fake their way through it and get good jobs without actually being any good, so I'll be fine with that. And most people are impressed with me because they just gave up entirely when they found out they weren't cut out for it. But the problem arises when I want to actually do things for myself, and I'm not good enough to be able to. I can ask other people to do it for me, but I don't like that idea. I don't want to have to rely on other people for things I'm also interested in. For one, I have to sacrifice my control over it, two I'll either have to burden someone or pay for it, and most importantly it takes all the fun and joy out of doing it myself. This is especially frustrating when everyone else I know is good enough to do things themselves, at least some of the things they're into, perhaps all of them.

parent.body:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome. Also, I still pick up new instruments now and then and have to struggle to learn. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.
parent.body_html:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome. Also, I still pick up new instruments now and then and have to struggle to learn. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.

post.body: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.
post.body_html: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.
post.title: Anyone out there who's closer to my talent level? I feel so alone here.

body: This is political propaganda. Be weary of these pieces, they are driven by a desire for money and power. I pray for those fooled by Donald Trump and other "Christian" politicians who promote the smug, self-righteous attitude and hypocrisy found in a lot of churches today. I too voted for Trump, because I think he makes better decisions for the country than Biden/Harris would, but that doesn't make him a god like many are treating him.
body_html: This is political propaganda. Be weary of these pieces, they are driven by a desire for money and power. I pray for those fooled by Donald Trump and other "Christian" politicians who promote the smug, self-righteous attitude and hypocrisy found in a lot of churches today. guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
